The CDKN2A allele encodes p16INK4a, a key regulator of the cell cycle by inhibiting CDK4/6, thereby preventing phosphorylation of RB1. Loss of CDKN2A function leads to uncontrolled cell proliferation. In the provided pathway, CDKN2A represses MDM2, which otherwise inactivates TP53. TP53 activates CDKN1A, which also inhibits CDK4/6. The APP allele contributes to **Alzheimer's Disease (AD)**. This pathway involves the amyloid beta precursor protein (APP), which is cleaved to produce amyloid-beta (Aβ), a key component of senile plaques in AD. Aβ activates muscarinic acetylcholine receptors (mAChR), triggering intracellular signaling through GNAQ, PLCB, IP3, and ITPR, leading to elevated cytosolic Ca²⁺. Excess Ca²⁺ is taken up by mitochondria via MCU, potentially inducing mitochondrial permeability transition (MPTP), which releases cytochrome c (CYCS) and triggers apoptosis. Dysregulation of this pathway is implicated in neurodegeneration and cognitive decline in Alzheimer's Disease.  
\boxed{Alzheimer's Disease}

The VHL gene is a tumor suppressor involved in the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway, regulating hypoxia-inducible factor (HIF) proteins. When dysfunctional, it leads to stabilization of HIF-1α and HIF-2α, promoting angiogenesis, cell proliferation, and survival. This pathway is represented here, with EPAS1 (HIF-2α) and ARNT forming a complex that activates VEGFA, CXCL8, GLUT1, and EPO. These genes drive vascular growth, inflammation, and erythropoiesis. Mutations in VHL cause von Hippel-Lindau disease, a hereditary cancer syndrome characterized by hemangioblastomas, renal cell carcinomas, and pheochromocytomas. The VHL allele's biological effect is thus the promotion of tumorigenesis and abnormal angiogenesis.

\boxed{Von Hippel-Lindau disease}

Mutations in PSEN1 lead to abnormal Aβ production, promoting the accumulation of Aβ plaques in the brain—a hallmark of Alzheimer's disease. Collectively, this pathway underscores the role of PSEN1 in the pathogenesis of Alzheimer's disease.

The PRKN gene encodes parkin, an E3 ubiquitin ligase involved in the ubiquitin-proteasome system. Mutations in PRKN are strongly associated with autosomal recessive early-onset Parkinson's disease (PD). Parkin plays a critical role in mitochondrial quality control by targeting damaged mitochondria for degradation via mitophagy. This contributes to the characteristic motor deficits seen in Parkinson's disease.

A defective NAGS allele leads to a complete deficiency of N-acetylglutamate, impairing CPS1 function and disrupting ammonia detoxification.
